question: A bivalent metal has an equivalent mass of 32. The molecular mass of the metal nitrate is
question_latex: A bivalent metal has an equivalent mass of 32. The molecular mass of the metal nitrate is
solution: Atomic mass of the metal $= 32 \times 2 = 64$. Formula of metal nitrate for a bivalent metal is $M(NO_3)_2$. Molecular mass $= 64 + 2(14 + 16 \times 3) = 64 + 28 + 96 = 188$.

question: What amount of calcium oxide will be produced by decomposition of 10 g calcium carbonate? [Atomic mass: Ca=40, C=12, O=16] [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: What amount of calcium oxide will be produced by decomposition of 10 g calcium carbonate? [Atomic mass: $Ca=40, C=12, O=16$] [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $CaCO_3 \rightarrow CaO + CO_2$. 100 g of $CaCO_3$ produces 56 g of $CaO$. Therefore, 10 g of $CaCO_3$ produces $5.6$ g of $CaO$.

question: Which of the following species has highest mass? [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Which of the following species has highest mass? [MHT-CET 2022]
options: B. 10 mL of water at room temperature
solution: (A) $0.5$ mol $CH_4 = 0.5 \times 16 = 8$ g. (B) 10 mL $H_2O = 10$ g. (C) $3.011 \times 10^{23}$ atoms $O = 0.5$ mol $O = 8$ g. (D) 1 mole $C = 12$ g. Hence, 1 mole of carbon atom has highest mass.

question: Which one of the following has maximum number of atoms of oxygen?
question_latex: Which one of the following has maximum number of atoms of oxygen?
solution: No. of O atoms: (A) $CO = \frac{2}{28} N_A \times 1$. (B) $CO_2 = \frac{2}{44} N_A \times 2 = \frac{1}{11} N_A$. (C) $SO_2 = \frac{2}{64} N_A \times 2 = \frac{1}{16} N_A$. (D) $H_2O = \frac{2}{18} N_A \times 1 = \frac{1}{9} N_A$. Since $1/9$ is largest, 2 g of $H_2O$ has max oxygen atoms.

question: Equivalent weight of a bivalent metal is 37.2. The molecular weight of its chloride is [MHT CET 2003]
question_latex: Equivalent weight of a bivalent metal is 37.2. The molecular weight of its chloride is [MHT CET 2003]
solution: Atomic weight of metal $= 37.2 \times 2 = 74.4$. Formula of chloride is $MCl_2$. Mol wt $= 74.4 + 2(35.5) = 145.4$.

question: 2.0 g of metal burnt in oxygen to form 3.2 g of its oxide. 1.42 g of same metal heated in steam to form 2.27 g of its oxide. Which law is verified by this data?
question_latex: 2.0 g of metal burnt in oxygen to form 3.2 g of its oxide. 1.42 g of same metal heated in steam to form 2.27 g of its oxide. Which law is verified by this data?
options: D. Law of conservation of mass
solution: Case 1: Ratio Metal:O $= 2.0 : 1.2 = 1.66:1$. Case 2: Ratio Metal:O $= 1.42 : 0.85 = 1.67:1$. Since the ratio is constant, it verifies the Law of definite proportion.

question: 2.76 g of silver carbonate on being strongly heated yields a residue weighing
question_latex: 2.76 g of silver carbonate on being strongly heated yields a residue weighing
solution: $Ag_2CO_3 \xrightarrow{\Delta} 2Ag + CO_2 + \frac{1}{2}O_2$. 276 g of $Ag_2CO_3$ yields 216 g of $Ag$. Thus, 2.76 g yields $\frac{216 \times 2.76}{276} = 2.16$ g.

question: Number of gram atoms of an element present in one atom of the element is [MHT-CET 2019]
question_latex: Number of gram atoms of an element present in one atom of the element is [MHT-CET 2019]
solution: Number of gram atoms (moles) $= \frac{\text{No. of atoms}}{N_A} = \frac{1}{6.022 \times 10^{23}} = 1.66 \times 10^{-24}$.

question: What is the volume occupied by 24 g methane gas at STP? [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: What is the volume occupied by 24 g methane gas at STP? [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: Molar mass of $CH_4 = 16$ g. 16 g occupies 22.4 $dm^3$. So, 24 g occupies $\frac{22.4 \times 24}{16} = 33.6$ $dm^3$.

question: Pure samples of copper carbonate synthesized in laboratory and found naturally if both contains 51.35% copper, 38.91% carbon and 9.74% oxygen by weight. This is in accordance with
question_latex: Pure samples of copper carbonate synthesized in laboratory and found naturally if both contains 51.35% copper, 38.91% carbon and 9.74% oxygen by weight. This is in accordance with
options: B. Law of conservation of mass
solution: The Law of Definite Proportion states that a given compound always contains its component elements in fixed ratio by mass, regardless of source.

question: What is the number of moles present in 1 m^3 of any gas at STP?
question_latex: What is the number of moles present in 1 $m^3$ of any gas at STP?

question: The number of water molecules in 1 L of water is
question_latex: The number of water molecules in 1 L of water is
solution: 1 L water $= 1000$ g. Moles $= 1000/18 = 55.55$. Molecules $= 55.55 \times N_A$.

question: x g of Ag was dissolved in HNO3 and the solution was treated with excess of NaCl when 2.87 g of AgCl was precipitated. The value of x is
question_latex: x g of $Ag$ was dissolved in $HNO_3$ and the solution was treated with excess of $NaCl$ when 2.87 g of $AgCl$ was precipitated. The value of x is
solution: $Ag \rightarrow AgCl$. 108 g $Ag$ produces 143.5 g $AgCl$. So, 2.87 g $AgCl$ is produced from $\frac{108 \times 2.87}{143.5} = 2.16$ g of $Ag$.

question: The number of gram molecules of chlorine in 6.02 x 10^25 hydrogen chloride molecules is
question_latex: The number of gram molecules of chlorine in $6.02 \times 10^{25}$ hydrogen chloride molecules is
solution: Moles of $HCl = 100$. $HCl$ contains 1 $Cl$ atom. Gram molecules of $Cl_2 = \text{moles of } Cl_2 = 100/2 = 50$.

question: On analysis a certain compound was found to contain iodine and oxygen in the ratio of 254 g of iodine (at. mass 127) and 80 g oxygen (at. mass 16). What is the formula of the compound?
question_latex: On analysis a certain compound was found to contain iodine and oxygen in the ratio of 254 g of iodine (at. mass 127) and 80 g oxygen (at. mass 16). What is the formula of the compound?
solution: Moles of $I = 254/127 = 2$. Moles of $O = 80/16 = 5$. Empirical formula $= I_2O_5$.

question: 4 g of copper was dissolved in concentrated nitric acid. The copper nitrate solution on strong heating gave 5 g of its oxide. The equivalent weight of copper is
question_latex: 4 g of copper was dissolved in concentrated nitric acid. The copper nitrate solution on strong heating gave 5 g of its oxide. The equivalent weight of copper is
solution: Mass of oxygen $= 5 - 4 = 1$ g. 1 g oxygen combines with 4 g $Cu$. 8 g oxygen (equivalent mass) combines with $4 \times 8 = 32$ g $Cu$.

question: If an iodized salt contains 1% KI and a person takes 2 g of the salt every day, the iodide ions going into his body every day would be approximately
question_latex: If an iodized salt contains 1% $KI$ and a person takes 2 g of the salt every day, the iodide ions going into his body every day would be approximately

question: A sample of a mixture of CaCl2 and NaCl weighing 4.22 g was treated to precipitate all the Ca as CaCO3. This CaCO3 is then heated and quantitatively converted into 0.959 g of CaO. Calculate the percentage of CaCl2 in the mixture.
question_latex: A sample of a mixture of $CaCl_2$ and $NaCl$ weighing 4.22 g was treated to precipitate all the $Ca$ as $CaCO_3$. This $CaCO_3$ is then heated and quantitatively converted into 0.959 g of $CaO$. Calculate the percentage of $CaCl_2$ in the mixture.
solution: 56 g $CaO \equiv 111$ g $CaCl_2$. So, 0.959 g $CaO = \frac{111 \times 0.959}{56} = 1.899$ g $CaCl_2$. Percentage $= \frac{1.899}{4.22} \times 100 = 45.04\%$.

question: 3 g of an oxide of a metal is converted to chloride completely and it yielded 5 g of chloride. The equivalent weight of the metal is
question_latex: 3 g of an oxide of a metal is converted to chloride completely and it yielded 5 g of chloride. The equivalent weight of the metal is
solution: $\frac{E+8}{E+35.5} = \frac{3}{5}$. Solving for $E$: $5E + 40 = 3E + 106.5 \rightarrow 2E = 66.5 \rightarrow E = 33.25$.

question: According to reaction, Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) -> MgCl2(aq) + H2(g); calculate the mass of Mg required to liberate 4.48 dm^3 H2 at STP. [Molar mass of Mg = 24 g/mol]
question_latex: $Mg_{(s)} + 2HCl_{(aq)} \longrightarrow MgCl_{2(aq)} + H_{2(g)}$; calculate the mass of $Mg$ required to liberate 4.48 $dm^3$ $H_2$ at STP. [Molar mass of $Mg = 24$ $g/mol$]

question: Calculate number of moles present in 9.10 x 10^-2 kg of water. [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Calculate number of moles present in $9.10 \times 10^{-2}$ kg of water. [MHT-CET 2024]

question: If 6.3 g of NaHCO3 are added to 15.0 g CH3COOH solution, the residue is found to weight 18.0 g. what is the mass of CO2 released in the reaction?
question_latex: If 6.3 g of $NaHCO_3$ are added to 15.0 g $CH_3COOH$ solution, the residue is found to weight 18.0 g. what is the mass of $CO_2$ released in the reaction?
solution: Total mass of reactants $= 6.3 + 15.0 = 21.3$ g. Mass of $CO_2 = 21.3 - 18.0 = 3.3$ g.

question: The units J Pa^-1 is equivalent to
question_latex: The units $J \ Pa^{-1}$ is equivalent to
solution: $J/Pa = \frac{N \cdot m}{N/m^2} = m^3$.

question: What is the volume occupied by 1 molecule of water, if it's density is 1 g cm^-3? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: What is the volume occupied by 1 molecule of water, if it's density is 1 $g \ cm^{-3}$? [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Mass of 1 molecule $= 18/N_A = 2.98 \times 10^{-23}$ g. Volume $= mass/density = 2.98 \times 10^{-23}$ $cm^3$.

question: The smallest matter particle that can take part in chemical reaction is
question_latex: The smallest matter particle that can take part in chemical reaction is
solution: According to Dalton's atomic theory, atoms are the smallest unit of matter participating in reactions.

question: Which of the following is an example of mixture? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Which of the following is an example of mixture? [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Sea water is a complex mixture of salts and water.

question: Carbon dioxide contains 27.27% of carbon, carbon disulphide contains 15.79% of carbon and sulphur dioxide contains 50% of sulphur. This data is an agreement with
question_latex: Carbon dioxide contains 27.27% of carbon, carbon disulphide contains 15.79% of carbon and sulphur dioxide contains 50% of sulphur. This data is an agreement with
options: A. Law of conservation of mass
solution: The ratios verify the Law of reciprocal proportions (Richter's Law).

question: Two oxides of a metal contain 50% and 40% metal (M) respectively. If the formula of fist oxide is MO2, the formula of second oxide will be
question_latex: Two oxides of a metal contain 50% and 40% metal (M) respectively. If the formula of fist oxide is $MO_2$, the formula of second oxide will be
solution: Oxide 1: 50% M, 50% O $\rightarrow$ M:O $= 1:1$. Since formula is $MO_2$, At mass $M = 32$. Oxide 2: 40% M, 60% O. Moles M $= 40/32 = 1.25$. Moles O $= 60/16 = 3.75$. Ratio $1:3$. Formula $MO_3$.

question: 80 g of oxygen contains as many atoms as in
question_latex: 80 g of oxygen contains as many atoms as in
solution: 80 g oxygen $= 5$ moles O atoms. 5 moles hydrogen $= 5$ g of hydrogen atoms.

question: The mass of BaCO3 produced when excess CO2 is bubbled through a solution of 0.205 mole Ba(OH)2 is,
question_latex: The mass of $BaCO_3$ produced when excess $CO_2$ is bubbled through a solution of 0.205 mole $Ba(OH)_2$ is,
solution: 0.205 mole $Ba(OH)_2 \equiv 0.205$ mole $BaCO_3$. Mass $= 0.205 \times 197 = 40.5$ g.

question: 100 tons of Fe2O3 containing 20% impurities will give iron by reduction with H2 equal to
question_latex: 100 tons of $Fe_2O_3$ containing 20% impurities will give iron by reduction with $H_2$ equal to
solution: Pure $Fe_2O_3 = 80$ tons. 160 g $Fe_2O_3$ yields 112 g Fe. So, 80 tons yield 56 tons.

question: Which of the following contains greatest number of oxygen atoms?
question_latex: Which of the following contains greatest number of oxygen atoms?
options: D. All have the same number of atoms
solution: All 1 g samples of oxygen (O, $O_2$, $O_3$) contain the same number of O atoms ($1/16 \times N_A$).

question: The number of hydrogen atoms present in 25.6 g of sucrose (C12H22O11) which has a molar mass of 342.3 g is

question: For the reaction, X + 2Y -> Z 5 Moles of X and 9 moles of Y will produce
question_latex: For the reaction, $X + 2Y \rightarrow Z$ 5 Moles of X and 9 moles of Y will produce
solution: Y is limiting. 2 moles Y produce 1 mole Z. So, 9 moles Y produce 4.5 moles Z.

question: What is the volume occupied by 2.5 mol of ammonia gas at STP? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: What is the volume occupied by 2.5 mol of ammonia gas at STP? [MHT-CET 2024]

question: Which of the following species has lowest mass? [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Which of the following species has lowest mass? [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: A: 18 g. B: 8 g. C: $0.25 \times 16 = 4$ g. D: 12 g. C is lowest.

question: Which of the following hydride does not obey law of constant proportion?
question_latex: Which of the following hydride does not obey law of constant proportion?
solution: Non-stoichiometric hydrides like $LaH_{x}$ do not obey constant proportions.

question: The percentage of P2O5 in diammonium hydrogen phosphate, (NH4)2HPO4 is
question_latex: The percentage of $P_2O_5$ in diammonium hydrogen phosphate, $(NH_4)_2HPO_4$ is
solution: Mol wt $(NH_4)_2HPO_4 = 132$. $P_2O_5 \equiv 2$ salt. Percentage $= \frac{142}{2 \times 132} \times 100 = 53.78\%$.

question: A metal nitride, M3N2 contains 28% of nitrogen. The atomic mass of metal, M is
question_latex: A metal nitride, $M_3N_2$ contains 28% of nitrogen. The atomic mass of metal, M is
solution: 28 g N $\equiv 72$ g M. 28 g N $= 2$ moles N. So, 2 moles N combines with 3 moles M. $3M = 72 \rightarrow M = 24$.

question: How many moles of methane are present in 11.2 L at S.T.P.?
question_latex: How many moles of methane are present in 11.2 L at S.T.P.?

question: Pure samples of copper carbonate synthesized in laboratory and found naturally if both contains 51.35% copper, 38.98% carbon and 9.74% oxygen by weight. This is an accordance with
question_latex: Pure samples of copper carbonate synthesized in laboratory and found naturally if both contains 51.35% copper, 38.98% carbon and 9.74% oxygen by weight. This is an accordance with
options: B. Law of conservation of mass
solution: Verified by consistency in mass percentages.

question: 2 g of metal carbonate is neutralised completely by 100mL of 0.1 (N) HCl. The equivalent weight of metal carbonate is
question_latex: 2 g of metal carbonate is neutralised completely by 100mL of 0.1 (N) HCl. The equivalent weight of metal carbonate is
solution: Equiv of HCl $= 0.1 \times 0.1 = 0.01$. Equiv weight $= 2/0.01 = 200$.

question: Gram molecular volume of oxygen at STP is
question_latex: Gram molecular volume of oxygen at STP is
solution: Standard GMV is 22.4 L.

question: Mixture X = 0.02 mole of [Co(NH3)5SO4] Br and 0.02 mole of [Co(NH3)5Br]SO4 was prepared in 2 L of solution. 1 L of mixture X + excess AgNO3 -> Y; 1 L of mixture X + excess BaCl2 -> Z. Number of moles of Y and Z are
question_latex: Mixture X = 0.02 mole of $[Co(NH_3)_5SO_4] Br$ and 0.02 mole of $[Co(NH_3)_5Br]SO_4$ was prepared in 2 L of solution. 1 L of mixture X + excess $AgNO_3 \rightarrow Y$; 1 L of mixture X + excess $BaCl_2 \rightarrow Z$. Number of moles of Y and Z are
solution: 1 L contains 0.01 mol of each. $Ag^+$ precipitates $Br^-$ (0.01 mol). $Ba^{2+}$ precipitates $SO_4^{2-}$ (0.01 mol).

question: How many moles of helium gas occupies 22.4 L at 0 C and at 1 atmospheric pressure? [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: How many moles of helium gas occupies 22.4 L at $0^{\circ}C$ and at 1 atmospheric pressure? [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: Standard molar volume condition.

question: Find the number of hydrogen atoms present in 6.0 g of urea (NH2CONH2).
question_latex: Find the number of hydrogen atoms present in 6.0 g of urea ($NH_2CONH_2$).
solution: Moles $= 6/60 = 0.1$. H atoms $= 0.1 \times 4 \times N_A = 2.4 \times 10^{23}$.

question: A 400 mg iron capsule contains 100 mg of ferrous fumarate, (CHCOO)2Fe. the percentage of iron present in it is approximately [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: A 400 mg iron capsule contains 100 mg of ferrous fumarate, $(CHCOO)_2Fe$. the percentage of iron present in it is approximately [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: Mass Fe $= (100 \times 56)/170 = 32.9$ mg. Percentage in 400 mg $= 32.9/400 \times 100 = 8.2\%$.

question_latex: Calculate mass in kg of 2.5 mole ammonia. [MHT-CET 2024]

question: Camphor is often used in molecular mass determination because
question_latex: Camphor is often used in molecular mass determination because
options: B. It has a very high cryoscopic constant
D. It is solvent for organic substances
solution: Camphor acts as a solid solvent which is volatile and has a high cryoscopic constant, facilitating molecular mass determination (Rast's method). Option (C) matches text rationale.

question: At constant temperature and pressure when 8 volumes of dihydrogen gas react with 4 volumes of dioxygen, the mass of water vapour produced is
question_latex: At constant temperature and pressure when 8 volumes of dihydrogen gas react with 4 volumes of dioxygen, the mass of water vapour produced is
solution: $2H_2 + O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O$. 8 vol $H_2$ + 4 vol $O_2 \rightarrow 8$ vol $H_2O$. Mass $= 8 \times 18 = 144$ g.

question: An aromatic hydrocarbon with empirical formula C6H4 on treatment with concentrated H2SO4 gave a monosulphonic acid. 0.104 g of the acid required 10 mL of N/20 NaOH for complete neutralisation. The molecular formula of hydrocarbon is
question_latex: An aromatic hydrocarbon with empirical formula $C_6H_4$ on treatment with concentrated $H_2SO_4$ gave a monosulphonic acid. 0.104 g of the acid required 10 mL of $\frac{N}{20}$ $NaOH$ for complete neutralisation. The molecular formula of hydrocarbon is
solution: Eq of acid = Eq of NaOH $= (1/20) \times 10 \times 10^{-3} = 5 \times 10^{-4}$. $M/n = 0.104 / (5 \times 10^{-4}) = 208$. Empirical formula $C_5H_4$ mass $= 64$. $n = 208/64 \approx 3$. Formula $= C_{15}H_{12}$.

question: Which property of an element is always a whole number?
question_latex: Which property of an element is always a whole number?
solution: Atomic number represents the number of protons, which is always an integer.

question: Number of atoms of He in 100 u of He (atomic weight of He is 4) are
question_latex: Number of atoms of He in 100 u of He (atomic weight of He is 4) are
solution: 1 atom $= 4$ u. 100 u contains $100/4 = 25$ atoms.

question: There are two isotopes of an element with atomic mass z. Heavier one has atomic mass z+2 and lighter one has z-1, the abundance of lighter one is
question_latex: There are two isotopes of an element with atomic mass z. Heavier one has atomic mass $z+2$ and lighter one has $z-1$, the abundance of lighter one is
solution: $z = \frac{x(z-1) + (100-x)(z+2)}{100} \Rightarrow 100z = xz - x + 100z + 200 - xz - 2x \Rightarrow 3x = 200 \Rightarrow x = 66.6\%$.

question: A sample of calcium carbonate has the following percentage composition. Ca=40%, C=12% and O=48% According to law of definite proportion the weight of calcium in 4g of a sample of calcium carbonate from another source will be
question_latex: A sample of calcium carbonate has the following percentage composition. $Ca=40\%$, $C=12\%$ and $O=48\%$ According to law of definite proportion the weight of calcium in 4g of a sample of calcium carbonate from another source will be
solution: $Ca$ is $40\%$ of $CaCO_3$. Weight in 4 g sample $= 4 \times 0.40 = 1.6$ g.

question: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
question_latex: Which of the following set of compounds does NOT demonstrate the law of multiple proportions?
solution: Multiple proportions law applies to compounds of the same two elements. $H_2O, CO_2, CH_4$ involve three different elements.

question: The volume of oxygen required for complete combustion of 0.25 mole of methane at S.T.P. is
question_latex: The volume of oxygen required for complete combustion of 0.25 mole of methane at S.T.P. is
solution: $CH_4 + 2O_2 \rightarrow CO_2 + 2H_2O$. 1 mole $CH_4$ requires 2 moles $O_2$. 0.25 mole requires 0.5 mole $O_2 = 11.2$ $dm^3$.

question: What quantity of oxygen is required for the complete combustion of 100 ml ethane under constant temperature and pressure? [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: What quantity of oxygen is required for the complete combustion of 100 ml ethane under constant temperature and pressure? [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $C_2H_6 + 3.5O_2 \rightarrow 2CO_2 + 3H_2O$. 1 vol ethane $\equiv 3.5$ vol oxygen. 100 ml ethane $\equiv 350$ ml oxygen.

question: Find out number of carbon atoms present in 0.35 mole of glucose.[2025]
question_latex: Find out number of carbon atoms present in 0.35 mole of glucose.[2025]
solution: C atoms $= 0.35 \times 6 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 1.2646 \times 10^{24}$.

question: What is the number of hydrogen atoms present in 5.4 g of urea?[2025]
question_latex: What is the number of hydrogen atoms present in 5.4 g of urea?\[2025\]
solution: Moles urea $= 0.09$. H atoms $= 0.09 \times 4 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 2.168 \times 10^{23}$.

question: If H2SO4 ionises as H2SO4 + 2H2O -> 2H3O+ + SO4^2-, then total number of ions produced by 0.1 M H2SO4 will be
question_latex: If $H_2SO_4$ ionises as $H_2SO_4 + 2H_2O \rightarrow 2H_3O^+ + SO_4^{2-}$, then total number of ions produced by 0.1 M $H_2SO_4$ will be
solution: 1 mol $H_2SO_4$ gives 3 moles of ions. 0.1 mol/L gives $0.3 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 1.8 \times 10^{23}$ ions (assuming 1L).

question: The number of sodium atoms in 2 moles of sodium ferrocyanide is
question_latex: The number of sodium atoms in 2 moles of sodium ferrocyanide is
solution: $Na_4[Fe(CN)_6]$. 1 mole has 4 Na atoms. 2 moles have 8 Na atoms $= 8 \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} = 4.8 \times 10^{24} = 48 \times 10^{23}$.

question: Air contains 20% O2 by volume. How much volume of air will be required for 100 cc of acetylene?
question_latex: Air contains $20\% O_2$ by volume. How much volume of air will be required for 100 cc of acetylene?
solution: $2C_2H_2 + 5O_2 \rightarrow 4CO_2 + 2H_2O$. 2 vol acetylene $\equiv 5$ vol $O_2$. 100 cc acetylene $\equiv 250$ cc $O_2$. Air required $= 250 / 0.20 = 1250$ cc.

question: If 20 g of CaCO3 is treated with 100 mL of 20% HCl solution, the amount of CO2 produced is
question_latex: If 20 g of $CaCO_3$ is treated with 100 mL of 20\% $HCl$ solution, the amount of $CO_2$ produced is
solution: $CaCO_3 + 2HCl \rightarrow CaCl_2 + CO_2 + H_2O$. 100 g $CaCO_3 \equiv 44$ g $CO_2$. 20 g $CaCO_3 \equiv 8.8$ g $CO_2$. HCl is in excess (20g).

question: A hydrocarbon contains 10.5 g carbon and 1 g hydrogen. Its 2.81 g has 1L volume at 1 atm and 127 C, hydrocarbon is
question_latex: A hydrocarbon contains 10.5 g carbon and 1 g hydrogen. Its 2.81 g has 1L volume at 1 atm and $127^{\circ}C$, hydrocarbon is
solution: Empirical formula: Moles $C = 10.5/12 = 0.875$, Moles $H = 1/1 = 1$. Ratio $C:H = 7:8 \Rightarrow C_7H_8$. Mol wt $= (2.81 \times 0.0821 \times 400) / (1 \times 1) = 92.2$. $C_7H_8$ mass is 92. Hence $C_7H_8$.

question: One gram mole of a gas at NTP occupies 22.4 L. This fact was derived from
question_latex: One gram mole of a gas at NTP occupies 22.4 L. This fact was derived from
solution: Avogadro's hypothesis states that equal volumes of gases at the same T and P contain equal molecules, leading to the molar volume constant.

question: Find the number of moles of sodium atoms in 6.9 x 10^-2 kg of it. [Atomic mass = 23 g/mol] [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Find the number of moles of sodium atoms in $6.9 \times 10^{-2}$ kg of it. [Atomic mass = 23 $g/mol$] [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Mass $= 69$ g. Moles $= 69/23 = 3.0$ mol.

question: In the reaction, 2KClO3(s) -> 2KCl(s) + 3O2(g). If 33.6 L of oxygen gas is liberated at STP, what is the mass of KCl(s) produced? (Atomic mass: K=39, Cl=35.5 g/mol) [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: $2KClO_{3(s)} \rightarrow 2KCl_{(s)} + 3O_{2(g)}$. If 33.6 L of oxygen gas is liberated at STP, what is the mass of $KCl_{(s)}$ produced? (Atomic mass: $K=39, Cl=35.5$ $g/mol$)
solution: 3 moles $O_2$ (67.2 L) $\equiv 2$ moles $KCl$ (149 g). So 33.6 L $O_2 \equiv 74.5$ g $KCl$.

question: Identify numerical value from following that has same value in C and F? [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: Identify numerical value from following that has same value in $^{\circ}C$ and $^{\circ}F$? [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $F = (9/5)C + 32$. If $F = C = x$, then $x = (9/5)x + 32 \Rightarrow -4x/5 = 32 \Rightarrow x = -40$.

question: If 0.5 mole of BaCl2 is mixed with 0.2 mole of Na3PO4, the maximum number of moles of Ba3(PO4)2 that can be formed is
question_latex: If 0.5 mole of $BaCl_2$ is mixed with 0.2 mole of $Na_3PO_4$, the maximum number of moles of $Ba_3(PO_4)_2$ that can be formed is
solution: $3BaCl_2 + 2Na_3PO_4 \rightarrow Ba_3(PO_4)_2 + 6NaCl$. $Na_3PO_4$ is limiting. 0.2 mole $Na_3PO_4$ forms 0.1 mole product.

question: The numerical value of N/n (where, N is the number of molecules in a given sample of gas and n is the number of moles of the gas) is
question_latex: The numerical value of $N/n$ (where, $N$ is the number of molecules and $n$ is number of moles) is
solution: $N = n \times N_A \Rightarrow N/n = N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23}$.

question: The formula mass of Mohr's salt is 392. The iron present in it is oxidised by KMnO4 in acid medium. The equivalent mass of Mohr's salt is
question_latex: The formula mass of Mohr's salt is 392. The iron present in it is oxidised by $KMnO_4$ in acid medium. The equivalent mass of Mohr's salt is
solution: In Mohr's salt, $Fe^{2+} \rightarrow Fe^{3+}$. $n$-factor is 1. Eq wt $= 392/1 = 392$.

question: Which has maximum number of atoms?
question_latex: Which has maximum number of atoms?
options: D. 4.48 L of CO2 at STP
solution: Atoms: (A) $2 \times 8 = 16$ mol. (B) 6 mol. (C) $5.5 \times 3 = 16.5$ mol. (D) $(4.48/22.4) \times 3 = 0.6$ mol. (C) is maximum.

question: KMnO4 (mol.wt. = 158) oxidizes oxalic acid in acid medium to CO2 and water as follows 5C2O4^2- + 2MnO4^- + 16H+ -> 10CO2 + 2Mn^2+ + 8H2O. What is the equivalent weight of KMnO4?
question_latex: $KMnO_4$ (mol.wt. = 158) oxidizes oxalic acid in acid medium to $CO_2$ and water. What is the equivalent weight of $KMnO_4$?
solution: $Mn^{7+} \rightarrow Mn^{2+}$. $n$-factor $= 5$. Eq wt $= 158/5 = 31.6$.

question: Calculate the number of Cl- ions in 333 g anhydrous calcium chloride? (At. mass Ca=40, Cl=35.5) [2025]
question_latex: Calculate the number of $Cl^-$ ions in 333 g anhydrous calcium chloride? (At. mass $Ca=40, Cl=35.5$)
solution: Moles $CaCl_2 = 333/111 = 3$. 1 mol $CaCl_2$ has 2 mol $Cl^-$. 3 mol $CaCl_2$ has 6 mol $Cl^- = 6 N_A$.

solution: 12 g $C \equiv 22.4$ $dm^3$. So 6 g $C \equiv 11.2$ $dm^3$.

B. Mixture of salt and sand grains

solution: $O_2$ and $O_3$ are allotropes of the same element, not different compounds of two elements.

question: One amu is equal to
question_latex: One amu is equal to
solution: 1 amu is $1/12$ mass of C-12, approx $1.6605 \times 10^{-24}$ g.

question: What is the mass of potassium chlorate required to liberate 6.72 dm^3 of oxygen gas at STP? (molar mass KClO3=122.5 g/mol) [2025]
question_latex: What is the mass of potassium chlorate required to liberate 6.72 $dm^3$ of oxygen gas at STP? (molar mass $KClO_3=122.5$ $g/mol$) [2025]
solution: $2KClO_3 \rightarrow 2KCl + 3O_2$. 3 mol $O_2$ (67.2 L) $\equiv 2$ mol $KClO_3$ (245 g). So 6.72 L $\equiv 24.5$ g.

question: The standard adopted for the determination of atomic weight of elements is based on
question_latex: The standard adopted for the determination of atomic weight of elements is based on
solution: Modern atomic weights are based on the carbon-12 isotope scale.

question: The number of significant figures in Avogadro's number is
question_latex: The number of significant figures in Avogadro's number is
options: D. Can be any of these
solution: In $6.022 \times 10^{23}$, there are four significant digits.

question: The equivalent weight of a certain trivalent element is 20. Molecular weight of its oxide is
question_latex: The equivalent weight of a certain trivalent element is 20. Molecular weight of its oxide is
solution: At mass $= 20 \times 3 = 60$. Oxide is $M_2O_3$. Mol wt $= (2 \times 60) + (3 \times 16) = 120 + 48 = 168$.

solution: Law requires compounds made of the same two elements. Set C contains three different combinations.

question: A gas is found to have formula [CO]x. Its vapour density is 70, the x is
question_latex: A gas is found to have formula $[CO]_x$. Its vapour density is 70, the x is
solution: Mol wt $= 2 \times 70 = 140$. $28x = 140 \Rightarrow x = 5$.

question: Which among the following elements has highest number of atoms in 1 g each? (At. No.: Au=197, Na=23, Cu=63.5, Fe=56)
question_latex: Which among the following elements has highest number of atoms in 1 g each? (At. No.: $Au=197, Na=23, Cu=63.5, Fe=56$)
solution: Moles in 1g $\propto 1/(\text{Atomic weight})$. Sodium ($Na$) has the smallest atomic weight among the options, so it has the most atoms.
